section.title: Using Sage to Study Groups
section.p: The group theory capabilities of Sage far exceeeds the scope of this book. In this section, we will concentrate on a few of the ideas we've discussed in this chapter.
Here is how to generate the group of integers modulo 23.

sage.output: Additive abelian group isomorphic to Z/23

section.p: Here is a direct product with factors of the group of integers modulo 2.
Here is how to generate a cyclic group with 14 elements.

There is no output from assigning G. The elements of G are generated from the list method. This group is isomorphic to \(\mathbb{Z}_{14}\). An isomorphism is suggested by the fact that when we multiply powers of \(f\), the exponents are added with \(+_{14}\). Among other things we can ask whether G is abelian and what its subgroups are.
The subgroups are identified by the groups to which they are isomorphic.

sage.output: [Multiplicative Abelian subgroup isomorphic to C2 x C7 generated by {f}, Multiplicative Abelian subgroup isomorphic to C7 generated by {f^2}, Multiplicative Abelian subgroup isomorphic to C2 generated by {f^7}, Trivial Abelian subgroup]

section.p: We focus on the second of these subgroups. Recall that the index for the second subgroup is 1 since all lists start with the 0 index in Sage.
